awd_titl_txt: 4-D Reconstruction of Magmatism at a long-lived Andesite Locus: Goat Rocks Volcanic Complex, Cascade Arc
awd_abstract_narration:
The large composite volcanoes that are distinctive of subduction zones are the surface expressions of the magma factory that distills mantle material to create and change the Earth’s crust. While the volcanoes themselves pose hazards to human health and property, the magma systems that drive them result in the circulation of hot water used for power and recreation, and also lead to the formation of many types of ore deposits at depth. For these reasons, the nature and development of subduction volcanoes and the magmatic underpinnings that feed them are critical. This project will investigate the long-term (~3 million year) development of the Goat Rocks Volcanic Complex, a cluster of eroded composite volcanoes in the Washington Cascade Range, to understand the origin and storage conditions of magmas erupted there and how they changed over time. Broader impacts of this study include the training of a female PhD student and undergraduate students in diverse field, laboratory, publication, and outreach skills; collaboration with the Washington Department of Natural Resources on projects and publications; and an animation of the development of the Cascade Volcanic Arc.

The Goat Rocks Volcanic Complex makes a particularly good natural laboratory because it is well exposed by glacial erosion, it is relatively young, and it spans a large part of the global compositional range of subduction zone stratovolcanoes. Preliminary work at the Goat Rocks Volcanic Complex indicates that the magma system changed substantially in time, from potassium-rich magmas stored at modest depth in the crust, to low-potassium and more water-rich magmas stored at greater depth. Detailed stratigraphy and geochronology (mainly 40Ar/39Ar dating) will provide a more robust time framework for the geochemical analyses of rocks and minerals to be used in reconstructing the magmatic history (e.g., pressure, temperature and water conditions), which will be quantified using computer models that couple mass and thermal balance. The reconstruction of this volcanic complex will then be compared to the magmatic histories of other subduction volcanoes in the Cascades and in other arcs. A particular aim is to evaluate conflicting models of magma generation and storage, i.e. (1) a model wherein deep crustal magma generation is prevalent, with only transient shallow storage before eruption; vs. (2) extensive interaction between crust and magma at all levels, as suggested by exposed sections of volcanic arc crust. We posit that seen through the lens of development in time, such models may be reconciled.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The intellectual merits of research on the Goat Rocks volcanic center:

  1. Mapping and dating and compositional analysis of the volcanic rocks have established that a major subduction-characteristic volcanic center existed there between 3.1 and 0.1 million years ago. The youngest ages suggest that future eruptions there are possible. The main magma types erupted were andesite and dacite (here grouped as andesitic) with minor rhyolites occurring early and late in the history.
  2. The main period of volcanic activity was from about 1.5-0.5 million years ago and produced a stratovolcanic complex (Lake Creek volcano) of the size of Mount Hood today. This volcano was the only major volcano in southern Washington Cascades in its day, predating the volcanoes Rainier, Adams and St. Helens, and overlapping in age with Mt. Hood.
  3. Basalts erupted on the periphery of the andesite-dacite locus throughout the history with maximum eruption rate producing shield volcanoes with many dozens of flows and heralding the maximum production rate in the andesite locus.
  4. There was a cycle of waxing climax and waning in the production of the andesitic magmas. Andesite genesis was fitful until the onset of abundant basalts, at which point large-volume (several tens of cubic kilometers) andesite flows erupted and are among the greatest in the world. Amphibole-bearing (and therefore more water-bearing) andesitic rocks became common during the most productive stage of stratovolcano volcanism. These andesitic volcanic rocks have mineral compositions indicating that magma storage was hottest, shallowest, and most integrated at this time. They are also richer in potassium and other elements that prefer being hosted in the melt rather than in minerals., which we interpret to be the result of parentage from basalts that have been so enriched through repeated recharge and crystal fractionation. Late andesitic magmas, while still amphibole-bearing were formed under cooler and deeper conditions related to waning of the thermal basalt pulse.
  5. Basalts were the primary material and thermal parents to the andesites. Crystal fractionation was dominant, recharge was critical during thermal climax and also fostered some crustal assimilation.
  6. Basalts are only of subduction-typical calcalkaline character, unlike the variety of basalts surrounding neighboring volcanoes. The basalts are derived from two mantle sources that were persistently tapped throughout the history of the volcanic center, with one having a slight influence of an enriched source that is likely a relict signature from addition of Siletzia mantle at the time the Siletzia terrane was accreted, causing subduction to step westward and initiating the Cascades arc.
  7. Compositional variety amongst andesitic rocks of the Goat Rocks  volcanic complex mimic across arc variation in modern time, indicating that a temporal perspective is need to understand variability in arc magmatism

 

With respect to broader impacts, this work contributes:

  1. A body of scientific papers for use by the scientific and broader community
  2. Training of students to the work force, particularly PhD student Kellie Wall now a post doc at the Cascade Volcano Observatory (USGS). William Gapasin, undergraduate who is now a masters student aiming at working in the mineral industry (he worked 2 years for mining companies). One UG now an MS student in library science, 2 UG students now in environmental geology, and one still enrolled in Earth Science, headed for science education.
  3. Collaboration between OSU  and other institutions, particularly with Dominique Weis at Univ. of British Columbia with respect to isotope data and understanding mantle domains, with Don Swanson (USGS) and Daryl Gusey (USFS) to expand the mapping, with Joe Biasi (CalTech) to understand paleomagnetic data from flows and dikes, and Gene Humphreys (Univ. of Oregon) to give Cascade-wide context.
  4. During her tenure at OSU, Wall was instrumental in establishing a state-wide graduate student group (Volc-OR) that meets yearly to share research and facilities information, including U of Oregon, Portland State U and Oregon State U.
  5. Owing to this work, the OSU argon geochronology lab has established sample preparation protocol to address the problem of melt inclusions in plagioclase in producing poor ages.
